content: The "Social Security and Medicare Lock-box Act of 2001" aims to prioritize the solvency of social security and Medicare by prohibiting the use of their surpluses for any other purpose until legislation is passed to extend their trust funds' solvency. The "Social Security and Medicare Lock-box Act of 2001" prohibits the use of surpluses for any other purpose until solvency legislation is enacted. The "Social Security and Medicare Lock-box Act of 2001" prohibits the use of surpluses for any other purpose until solvency legislation is enacted. The conference report outlines the definition of baseline budget surpluses and projections according to the Congressional Budget Office. The baseline budget projection includes on-budget and off-budget outlays and receipts. A portion of the baseline budget surpluses is used if legislation affecting revenues or direct spending is not offset by corresponding reductions or increases. The text chunk discusses criteria for budget legislation, including requirements for offsetting increases in spending and certifications for social security and Medicare solvency. The subsection defines 'Medicare solvency certification' as a certification by the Board of Trustees of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund indicating actuarial balance for a 30-year period. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 require a supermajority for certain sections. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act takes effect upon enactment and applies to fiscal year 2001 and subsequent years.
